messages.subject: Re: [UnschoolingDiscussion] Goat´s Milk not for mula
messages.msgSnippet: Or, look at it this way: Goat milk is easier to digest and less allergenic than cow s milk or soy milk --which is the base for non-dairy formulas. So, if you
messages.messageBody:
Or, look at it this way: Goat milk is easier to digest and less
allergenic than cow's milk or soy milk --which is the base for
non-dairy formulas. So, if you cannot BF, might as well go with goat
milk.

Then again, I did neither. After I stopped nursing, I gave my kids
fortified rice milk because it is waaaaaaaaaaaaay more hypoallegenic
than goat milk. Goat yogurt has become "de rigueur" for most of our
cooking needs and I use Meyenberg Goat Milk for my coffee --became
sensitive to CM maybe after having Evan, certainly after Aidan was born.

liza, nyc
mom of Evan (6) and Aidan (3.5)


On Sunday, September 21, 2003, at 03:05 AM, Christine Kuglen wrote:

> Following this discussion is interesting. Just an intereting FYI, when
> i was taking a course for my Lactation Educator Certificate we learned
> that there is a scale from best to worse for baby...
> 1)mother´s milk from breast
> 2)mother´s milk from bottle or other feeding device
> 3)donated mother´s milk
> 4)goat´s milk with folic acid added
> 5) formula
>
> Basically, formula is cow´s milk(which is meant for baby cow´s)
> changed a little.
>
> -Christine

messages.messageBody:

messages.subject: Goat´s Milk not formula
messages.msgSnippet: Following this discussion is interesting. Just an intereting FYI, when i was taking a course for my Lactation Educator Certificate we learned that there is a
messages.messageBody:
Following this discussion is interesting. Just an intereting FYI, when i was taking a course for my Lactation Educator Certificate we learned that there is a scale from best to worse for baby...
1)mother´s milk from breast
2)mother´s milk from bottle or other feeding device
3)donated mother´s milk
4)goat´s milk with folic acid added
5) formula

Basically, formula is cow´s milk(which is meant for baby cow´s) changed a little.

-Christine

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
